11:09 <@sdumitriu> vmassol: It's the user vs repo ignores discussion  
11:09 <@sdumitriu> It's debatable  
11:09 <@sdumitriu> Each user would have to configure the global ignores, but there are few users than repos  
11:09 <@sdumitriu> fewer committers than repos  
11:10 <@sdumitriu> Do you want to put gitignores in all 50 repos?  
11:10 <vmassol> yes  
11:11 <vmassol> it's better than having to put gitignores in 5000 repos  
11:11 <vmassol> ;)  
11:11 <vmassol> (all users who'd clone/fork xwiki repos)  
11:11 <vmassol> I'll do it anyway, I don't think there's any harm in doing os  
11:11 <vmassol> so  
11:11 <@sdumitriu> K  
11:11 <vmassol> users can still do it locally if they want  
11:12 <vmassol> sdumitriu: I've also updated http://incubator.myxwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/Main/UsingGitHub#HIntroduceyourselftogit  
11:12 <vmassol> (with my .gitconfig example  
11:12 <vmassol> )

11:15 <vmassol> (it prints the branch in your prompt)  
11:18 <+sburjan> hello. I have a question regarding XEM. After installing it, I want to create a default template. But it seems I am not able to control the database name which is created automatically by the XEM when installing the default template. This basically makes impossible to use 2 XEM's on the same machine, because the default template used will be shared among the two instances (because both will seek for the default template). Any idea what can I  
11:18 <+sburjan>  do ?  
11:20 <@cjdelisl1> run 2 mysqld's on different ports?  
11:20 <aravindbhms\_> has quit  
11:21 <+sburjan> yes, but I don't think this will solve the issue.  
11:23 <+sburjan> I mean, I am on a 2.7.1 XEM and creating a default template, which is hardcoded and named templatexe. Then, I go on a 3.0 XEM and create the default template. I guess the 3.0 will override the 2.7.1 or see it as already existing. And I'm not sure that creating a subwiki on 2.7.1 will not actually instantiate a 3.0 XE because of the template  
11:23 <+sburjan> I think the best person to ask this is Thomas

12:01 <@cjdelisle> I read that github uses MongoDB internally

12:06 <tmortagne> has joined #xwiki  
12:06 <vmassol> (that was for cjdelisle)  
12:06 <bark> has joined #xwiki  
12:06 <@cjdelisle> oh right... that  
12:06 <@cjdelisle> manual :P  
12:06 <vmassol> but I'm not sure yet if I'll use gitmodules  
12:08 <@cjdelisle> hmm pull requests? That seems like a complicated way to go.  
12:09 <vmassol> yes I agree  
12:09 <vmassol> I'm replying to sdumitriu  
12:09 <@cjdelisle> If there was one person in charge of saying yes or no to everything then it would make sense.  
12:09 <@cjdelisle> But with a group of committers it's a bit redundant.  
12:10 <vmassol> I've heard people do C but I don't like too much for the following reasons:  
12:10 <vmassol> \* It means finding a developer to review every time which IMO is going to either be very hard to do or that developer will simply approve it without really reviewing the code  
12:10 <vmassol> \* It means the master branch will be slow to have the latest changes which means our CI tests won't run as often on them (only close to release dates) which is bad and will make code integration harder  
12:10 <vmassol> \* Side note: Even though Git encourages developers to keep their work locally without sharing them we should \*\*NOT\*\* do this and developers should continue to commit every day and not keep code on their machines. This prevents code integration and code reviews. It's easy to casually review 15 lines of code, it's very hard to review 300 lines of code!  
12:10 <vmassol> \* Since mails (and diff mails) will continue to be sent code reviews will still be done as before. This is lazy code reviewing and is IMO much better than forced code reviews which I don't see working. It would be a good strategy if we were building a software to send man to Mars for example but for XWiki I favor a lazy code reviewing approach (what we've been  doing).  
12:10 <vmassol> So 1A for me.  
12:11 <arkub> has quit  
12:11 <vmassol> ok lunch time  
12:12 <@cjdelisle> heh I thought at first that was a complaint about the C language.  
12:13 <Chami1> has left #xwiki  
12:15 <@cjdelisle> My thinking is just that git is just a different SCM. Pull requests are a whole different philosophy which we currently don't use.  
12:16 <@cjdelisle> It works well when there is one person (Linus) who has final word on what gets shipped.  
12:16 <bark> has quit  
12:17 <@cjdelisle> But in our case it would be rather silly to do a pull request when we have the power to fullfill our own request.

12:19 <nuvolari> has joined #xwiki  
12:19 <nuvolari> has quit

12:19 <sbose78> hi, I wish to have a talk regarding the "XWiki TO APPENGINE " project.  
12:20 <@cjdelisle> what would you like to talk about?  
12:20 <nuvolari\_> has quit  
12:20 <sbose78> http://platform.xwiki.org/xwiki/bin/view/DevGuide/QueryGuide   I went through the guide.  
12:21 <sbose78> and I feel the project is my cup of tea. Could I have some more insight about the project. I feel I have understood clearly what is to be done.  
12:22 <@cjdelisle> and how do you plan on doing it?  
12:22 <sbose78> I plan to use XML to group the various query components.  
12:23 <@sdumitriu> sbose78: You can send a mail to [[email protected]](https://dev.xwiki.org/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection) with your current plan and ask for feedback  
12:23 <@sdumitriu> cjdelisle can help you here quickly  
12:23 <sbose78> Sure.  
12:23 <@cjdelisle> using cjdelisle and help in the same sentence is dangerous ;)  
12:24 <sbose78> XML can be used to parse the query into Datastore compliant queries  
12:24 <sbose78> :)  
12:24 <@cjdelisle> You are able to do parsing using XML?  
12:24 <sbose78> Yes  
12:25 <sbose78> That's not a big deal for me, honestly. iText libraries can be used ( if not something better)  
12:26 <@cjdelisle> Do you have a link about this? I didn't know it was possible to parse using XML.  
12:27 <sbose78> Nope, dont have a link right now.  
12:27 <sbose78> I planned it on my own actually  
12:28 <sbose78> How long does it take to get a reply in the mailing lists?  
12:28 <@sdumitriu> Depends on the workload  
12:28 <@sdumitriu> It can take from 5 minutes to 5 days  
12:28 <sbose78> Cool :)  
12:29 <@cjdelisle> I wonder if we should have some kind of plan for avoiding compatability lockin with google.  
12:29 <silviar> has joined #xwiki  
12:30 <@cjdelisle> I only mention that because google is not compatable with anything else.  
12:30 <bark> has joined #xwiki  
12:34 <sbose78> has quit  
12:34 <fmancinelli> didn't understand this XML + parsing + iText (a pdf generation library?!?) thing... What are you talking about exactly?

12:37 <@cjdelisle> \*shrug\* I've never heard of parsing with XML, if he can pull it off then I suppose he can do anything.

14:20 <SvenDowideit> has quit  
14:20 <SvenDowideit> has joined #xwiki  
14:34 <@cjdelisle> "For instance, an app cannot spawn threads, write data to the local file system or make arbitrary network connections. An app also cannot use JNI or other native code"  
14:34 <@cjdelisle> http://code.google.com/appengine/docs/java/overview.html  
14:35 <@cjdelisle> Not sure if by "threads" they mean processes or threads. If threads then I'm not sure XWiki App Engine is a realistic goal.  
14:43 <@cjdelisle> "A Java application cannot create a new java.lang.ThreadGroup nor a new java.lang.Thread."  
14:43 <@cjdelisle> D:  
14:49 <fmancinelli> cjdelisle: yep, it's java.lang.Thread  
14:51 <fmancinelli> cjdelisle: though they have this "Task queues" service which can be used instead  
14:52 <@cjdelisle> I could write a few pages of changes we would have to make.  
14:52 <@cjdelisle> So IMO making storage function with their BigTable would probably go to waste.  
14:54 <silviar> has quit  
14:54 <@cjdelisle> Probably the biggest issue is third party libraries. We can route out all of our locations that write to disk or spawn threads but can we be sure groovy doesn't ever spawn a thread?  
14:56 <@sdumitriu> Groovy works on AppEngine, AFAIK  
14:56 <@sdumitriu> But we're using ThreadLocal, and I'm not sure if that will work or not  
15:00 <fmancinelli> ThreadLocal is on the whitelist, so it works (http://code.google.com/appengine/docs/java/jrewhitelist.html)  
15:01 <@cjdelisle> Is the gsoc project to get xwiki running on app engine or to get the XWQL thing to run queries against bigtable?  
15:02 <Chami1> has left #xwiki  
15:03 <fmancinelli> cjdelisle: Ludovic's idea basically is to do both, AFAIU :)  
15:04 <vmassol> important mail sent!  
15:08 <@cjdelisle> #1 lucine will have to go. There is just no way it can function without a separate thread.  
15:09 <+sburjan> vmassol: regarding you mail. why do you say "see if we keep extensions.xwiki.org" where would those extension go ?  
15:09 <vmassol> mflorea: why don't you create the perf eval doc in the design space of xwiki.org?  
15:09 <+sburjan> \*your  
15:10 <vmassol> sdumitriu: same question for the git guide, why didn't you start it inth edraft space of xwiki.org?  
15:10 <vmassol> trying to understand why people go on incubator....  
15:10 <vmassol> (when tehre are places on xwiki.org for that)  
15:10 <vmassol> sburjan: I've put one solution in the mail

15:11 <vmassol> still….  
15:11 <vmassol> there could be 2 pages in the design part  
15:11 <vmassol> could also go indrat  
15:11 <vmassol> draft  
15:12 <+mflorea> I can move it to draft space  
15:12 <+mflorea> on xwiki.org  
15:12 <vmassol> (haven't read your mails yet, just received them)  
15:12 <vmassol> (but I go my watchlist on myxwiki.org showing me your changes there ;))  
15:13 <+mflorea> :)  
15:21 <evalica> has joined #xwiki  
15:21 <abusenius\_> has joined #xwiki  
15:25 <@cjdelisle> fmancinelli: The things which create new FileOutputStream:  
15:26 <@cjdelisle> extension manager, pdf exporter, chart macro, attachments (even prior to filesystem attachments), ExportURLFactory (html export), JarProxy (part of the XWiki classloader), AbstractOfficeViewer, DefaultOpenOfficeConverter  
15:26 <vmassol> devs please reply to "[VOTE] Directory/Git Reorganization re platform vs extensions" asap since there's a lot of work to be done urgently if we agree  
15:26 <vmassol> sdumitriu, tmortagne1 should be easy for you to reply to it ;)  
15:27 <tmortagne1> :)

15:38 <@cjdelisle> AFAICT the general consept of app engine is it's stateless, IE your app may run on any box that isn't busy at the time. XWiki is most definitely not stateless.
